properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:

Wind gusts to 35 knots may be possible with this line. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues today. Snow will continue today, with an additional 5 centimetres expected. This will result in total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm by this evening. Local total snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are possible near the Minnesota Border. However in general, the criterion for snowfall warning is not expected to be reached across Northwestern Ontario. Strong easterly winds with gusts to 60 km/h will also generate occasional blowing snow giving reduced visibilities. Hazardous winter driving conditions due to low visibility in occasional heavy snow and blowing snow, and accumulating snow on untreated roads are expected. The heaviest snowfall associated with this Colorado Low will remain south of the international border where Winter Storm Warnings are in effect. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-12T23:08:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T15:09:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0931402578.2019
Area: Fort Frances - Emo - Rainy River, Seine River Village - Mine Centre, Atikokan - Shebandowan - Quetico Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: Flood Watch Continued For All Points Along The Roseau River
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Watch for all points along the Roseau River due to expected high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-04-13T11:15:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-12T11:24:25-05:00, B6EF896F-E95B-94A7-B238-F843D5A3653E
Area: All points along the Roseau River
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall possible today. Freezing rain will change to rain this morning before ending by late afternoon. Isolated thunderstorms are also expected mainly this morning. Significant rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm are possible, especially in areas that see a thunderstorm. Local ponding on streets and low lying areas is possible. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-12T22:30:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T14:31:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1243724248.2019
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring snow expected for many southern mountain passes on Saturday. A Pacific frontal system will move across southern BC on Saturday. Snow will develop over the highway passes beginning early in the morning. Initially, snow levels will be near 800 metres and gradually rise to 1200 metres that afternoon. Near the Coquihalla summit and the Kootenay Pass, 10 to 15 cm of snow can be expected by Saturday afternoon. Additional amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible Saturday night as convective flurries develop in the wake of the front. Snowfall over other southern BC highway passes will be less intense and total amounts nearer 5 cm can be expected on Saturday. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T02:19:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T18:20:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0861030210.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for Newfoundland next week. Meteorologists are monitoring a developing weather system that appears set to affect the Island for the first half of next week. While it is too soon to provide specific details, indications point toward a prolonged event with strong winds and a variety of precipitation types. Precipitation will likely arrive over southwestern Newfoundland on Monday morning and spread across the Island during the day. It appears most areas will receive snow on the leading edge of the system before a transition through freezing rain to rain. Over northern Newfoundland, however, precipitation may remain as mainly snow. Some temporary improvement can be expected during the day on Tuesday, but colder air will follow from west to east Tuesday night into Wednesday, changing precipitation back to snow, with potential for accumulation. Strong easterly winds will develop over most areas on Monday and continue through Monday night before easing on Tuesday. Gusty northerly winds will then likely follow for Tuesday night into Wednesday. The northerlies should subside Wednesday night as the system finally pulls away. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-13T03:06:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T19:07:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3725665840.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixed bag of wintery precipitation today. Snow, mixed with ice pellets and possibly some freezing rain will briefly change over to rain or a rain and wet snow mix later today as temperatures edge above the zero degree mark. Precipitation will change back to snow this evening. Total snow and ice pellet amounts will range from just a couple centimetres in the Kapuskasing and Little Abitibi areas up to 10 cm in a swath of regions from near Hearst to the Marathon - Schreiber area. Poor winter driving conditions are expected. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. This messy winter weather is courtesy of a Colorado Low which will track from the US Midwest across Lake Superior to James Bay by Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-12T22:34:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T14:35:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1746598532.2019
Area: Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Marathon - Schreiber, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds continue to cause blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains. Winds are forecast to ease somewhat near midday and reintensify this evening. The winds will likely remain strong through to at least Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T09:27:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T17:28:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1842201617.2019
Area: Dempster
